rev.diff:
Line 36: Line 36:
[[Emergency law in Egypt|Emergency Law]] (Law No. 162 of 1958) was enacted after the 1967 [[Six-Day War]], suspended for 18 months in the early 1980s,<ref name="emerlaw">[http://www.emerglobal.com/lex/law-1958-162 Law 1958/162 (Emergency Law)] {{ar}} at [http://www.emerglobal.com/lex EMERglobal Lex] January 2011, part of the [[Edinburgh Middle East Report]]. Retrieved 2 April 2010.</ref> and continuously in effect since President Sadat's 1981 assassination.<ref name="eohr2008">{{Cite web|last=Egyptian Organisation for Human Rights|title=Egypt and The Impact of 27 years of Emergency on Human Rights|url=http://en.eohr.org/2008/05/28/%E2%80%9Cegypt-and-the-impact-of-27-years-of-emergency-on-human-rights%E2%80%9D/#more-22|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20110129202417/http://en.eohr.org/2008/05/28/%E2%80%9Cegypt-and-the-impact-of-27-years-of-emergency-on-human-rights%E2%80%9D/#more-22|archivedate=29 January 2011|accessdate=29 January 2011|date=28 May 2008}}</ref> Under the law, police powers are extended, [[Constitution of Egypt|constitutional rights]] suspended, [[censorship]] is legalised,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://conconflicts.ssrc.org/mideast/shehata/|title=Egypt After 9/11: Perceptions of the United States|date=26 March 2004|accessdate=30 January 2011|last=Shehata|first=Samer|work=Contemporary Conflicts}}</ref> and the government may imprison individuals indefinitely and without reason. The law sharply limits any non-governmental political activity, including [[Demonstration (people)|street demonstrations]], non-approved political organisations, and unregistered financial donations.<ref name="emerlaw"/> The Mubarak government has cited the threat of [[terrorism]] in order to extend the emergency law,<ref name="eohr2008"/> claiming that opposition groups like the [[Muslim Brotherhood in Egypt|Muslim Brotherhood]] could come into power in Egypt if the current government did not forgo parliamentary elections and suppressed the group through actions allowed under emergency law.<ref name="autogenerated2004">{{Cite book|last= Caraley|first= Demetrios|title= American Hegemony: Preventive War, Iraq, and Imposing Democracy|publisher=[[Academy of Political Science]]|year= 2004|month= April|isbn= 1-8848-5304-8}}</ref> This has led to the imprisonment of activists without trials,<ref name="Egyptian bloggers brave police intimidation">{{Cite web|author=Choney, Suzanne|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/41285248/ns/technology_and_science-tech_and_gadgets/|title=Egyptian bloggers brave police intimidation|accessdate=28 January 2011|date=27 January 2011|work=[[MSNBC]]}}</ref> illegal undocumented hidden detention facilities,<ref name="Mayer">{{Cite web|url=http://www.newyorker.com/archive/2006/10/30/061030ta_talk_mayer|title=The C.I.A.'s Travel Agent|date= 30 October 2006|accessdate=28 January 2011|work=The New Yorker |author=Mayer, Jane}}</ref><ref name="Kalla fakta">{{Cite web|url=http://www.trojkan.se/temp/Reportage/KF_Extraordinary_Rendition/English_version/The%20Broken%20Promise%20-%20%20How%20we%20did%20it.doc|title=Striptease brevpapperl Agent|date= 18 May 2004|accessdate=28 January 2011|publisher=http://www.trojkan.se|author=Kalla fakta}}</ref> and rejecting university, mosque, and newspaper staff members based on their political inclination.<ref name="independents fight for hearts and minds">{{Cite web|author=Shenker, Jack|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2010/nov/22/egypt-elections-muslim-brotherhood-ndp|title=Egyptian elections: independents fight for hearts and minds in 'fixed ballot'|work=The Guardian |location=UK|date=22 November 2010|accessdate=28 January 2011}}</ref> A [[Egyptian parliamentary election, 2010|parliamentary election]] in December 2010 was preceded by a media crackdown, arrests, candidate bans (particularly of the Muslim Brotherhood), and allegations of fraud involving the near unanimous victory by the ruling party in parliament.<ref name="emerlaw"/> Human rights organisations estimate that in 2010 between 5,000 and 10,000 people were in long-term detention without charge or trial.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Amnesty International|title=Egypt: Keep Promise to Free Detainees by End of June|url=http://www.amnesty.org/en/library/info/MDE12/027/2010/en|accessdate=29 January 2011|date=29 June 2010}}</ref><ref name="Death Triggers Cairo Protests">{{Cite web|author=Holder, R. Clemente|url=http://www.washington-report.org/backissues/0794/9407060.htm|title=Egyptian Lawyer's Death Triggers Cairo Protests|work=[[Washington Report on Middle East Affairs]]|date=July/August 1994|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref>
[[Emergency law in Egypt|Emergency Law]] (Law No. 162 of 1958) was enacted after the 1967 [[Six-Day War]], suspended for 18 months in the early 1980s,<ref name="emerlaw">[http://www.emerglobal.com/lex/law-1958-162 Law 1958/162 (Emergency Law)] {{ar}} at [http://www.emerglobal.com/lex EMERglobal Lex] January 2011, part of the [[Edinburgh Middle East Report]]. Retrieved 2 April 2010.</ref> and continuously in effect since President Sadat's 1981 assassination.<ref name="eohr2008">{{Cite web|last=Egyptian Organisation for Human Rights|title=Egypt and The Impact of 27 years of Emergency on Human Rights|url=http://en.eohr.org/2008/05/28/%E2%80%9Cegypt-and-the-impact-of-27-years-of-emergency-on-human-rights%E2%80%9D/#more-22|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20110129202417/http://en.eohr.org/2008/05/28/%E2%80%9Cegypt-and-the-impact-of-27-years-of-emergency-on-human-rights%E2%80%9D/#more-22|archivedate=29 January 2011|accessdate=29 January 2011|date=28 May 2008}}</ref> Under the law, police powers are extended, [[Constitution of Egypt|constitutional rights]] suspended, [[censorship]] is legalised,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://conconflicts.ssrc.org/mideast/shehata/|title=Egypt After 9/11: Perceptions of the United States|date=26 March 2004|accessdate=30 January 2011|last=Shehata|first=Samer|work=Contemporary Conflicts}}</ref> and the government may imprison individuals indefinitely and without reason. The law sharply limits any non-governmental political activity, including [[Demonstration (people)|street demonstrations]], non-approved political organisations, and unregistered financial donations.<ref name="emerlaw"/> The Mubarak government has cited the threat of [[terrorism]] in order to extend the emergency law,<ref name="eohr2008"/> claiming that opposition groups like the [[Muslim Brotherhood in Egypt|Muslim Brotherhood]] could come into power in Egypt if the current government did not forgo parliamentary elections and suppressed the group through actions allowed under emergency law.<ref name="autogenerated2004">{{Cite book|last= Caraley|first= Demetrios|title= American Hegemony: Preventive War, Iraq, and Imposing Democracy|publisher=[[Academy of Political Science]]|year= 2004|month= April|isbn= 1-8848-5304-8}}</ref> This has led to the imprisonment of activists without trials,<ref name="Egyptian bloggers brave police intimidation">{{Cite web|author=Choney, Suzanne|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/41285248/ns/technology_and_science-tech_and_gadgets/|title=Egyptian bloggers brave police intimidation|accessdate=28 January 2011|date=27 January 2011|work=[[MSNBC]]}}</ref> illegal undocumented hidden detention facilities,<ref name="Mayer">{{Cite web|url=http://www.newyorker.com/archive/2006/10/30/061030ta_talk_mayer|title=The C.I.A.'s Travel Agent|date= 30 October 2006|accessdate=28 January 2011|work=The New Yorker |author=Mayer, Jane}}</ref><ref name="Kalla fakta">{{Cite web|url=http://www.trojkan.se/temp/Reportage/KF_Extraordinary_Rendition/English_version/The%20Broken%20Promise%20-%20%20How%20we%20did%20it.doc|title=Striptease brevpapperl Agent|date= 18 May 2004|accessdate=28 January 2011|publisher=http://www.trojkan.se|author=Kalla fakta}}</ref> and rejecting university, mosque, and newspaper staff members based on their political inclination.<ref name="independents fight for hearts and minds">{{Cite web|author=Shenker, Jack|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2010/nov/22/egypt-elections-muslim-brotherhood-ndp|title=Egyptian elections: independents fight for hearts and minds in 'fixed ballot'|work=The Guardian |location=UK|date=22 November 2010|accessdate=28 January 2011}}</ref> A [[Egyptian parliamentary election, 2010|parliamentary election]] in December 2010 was preceded by a media crackdown, arrests, candidate bans (particularly of the Muslim Brotherhood), and allegations of fraud involving the near unanimous victory by the ruling party in parliament.<ref name="emerlaw"/> Human rights organisations estimate that in 2010 between 5,000 and 10,000 people were in long-term detention without charge or trial.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Amnesty International|title=Egypt: Keep Promise to Free Detainees by End of June|url=http://www.amnesty.org/en/library/info/MDE12/027/2010/en|accessdate=29 January 2011|date=29 June 2010}}</ref><ref name="Death Triggers Cairo Protests">{{Cite web|author=Holder, R. Clemente|url=http://www.washington-report.org/backissues/0794/9407060.htm|title=Egyptian Lawyer's Death Triggers Cairo Protests|work=[[Washington Report on Middle East Affairs]]|date=July/August 1994|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref>

===Police brutality===
+
===Brutality===
  +
[[File:Police in civilian cloth beating a protester in Cairo 1.png|thumb|175px|Baltageya beating a protester in Cairo]]
{{main|Law enforcement in Egypt}}
{{main|Law enforcement in Egypt}}
â
+
The deployment of plainclothes forces paid by Mr. Mubarakâs ruling party, ''Baltageya'' ({{lang-ar|Ø¨ÙØ·Ø¬ÙØ©}}), has been a hallmark of the Mubarak government.<ref name="Gunfire Rings Out as Protesters Clash">{{Cite news|author=David KirkpAtrick|coauthors=Kareem Fahim|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/26/world/middleeast/26egypt.html|title=Gunfire Rings Out as Protesters Clash|work=The New York Times |date=03 February 2011| accessdate=03 February 2011}}</ref> A leaked US embassy cable from 2009 described [[police brutality]], including [[torture]], as common and pervasive, and the government's efforts to combat it as ineffective and lacking in political will.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/us-embassy-cables-documents/187359|title=US embassy cables: Police brutality in Egypt|work=The Guardian |location=UK|date 28 January 2011|accessdate=29 January 2011}}</ref> The [[Egyptian Organisation for Human Rights]] has documented 567 cases of torture, including 167 deaths, by police that occurred between 1993 and 2007.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/6943704.stm|title=Egyptian police sued for boy's death|publisher=BBC News|date=13 August 2007|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref> On 6 June 2010 [[Death of Khaled Mohamed Saeed|Khaled Mohamed Saeed died under disputed circumstances]] in the [[Sidi Gaber]] area of [[Alexandria]]. Multiple witnesses testified that Saeed was beaten to death by the police.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/anger-alexandria-we%E2%80%99re-afraid-our-own-government|title=Anger in Alexandria: 'We're afraid of our own government'|work=[[Almasry Alyoum]]|date=25 June 2010|accessdate=13 July 2010}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Two witnesses affirm Alexandria victim beaten by police|author=|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/two-witnesses-affirm-alex-victim-beaten-police|work=[[Almasry Alyoum]]|date=19 June 2010|accessdate=26 January 2011}}</ref> Activists rallying around a Facebook page called "We are all Khaled Said" succeeded in bringing nationwide attention to the case.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Levinson |first=Charles |url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748703445904576118502819408990.html |title=Wall Street Journal |work=The Wall Street Journal |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> [[Mohamed ElBaradei]], former head of the [[International Atomic Energy Agency]], led a rally in Alexandria against alleged abuses by the police and visited Saeed's family to offer condolences.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2010/06/201062642955204618.html|title=ElBaradei leads anti-torture rally|publisher=Al Jazeera English|date=26 June 2010|accessdate=13 July 2010}}</ref>
â
A leaked US embassy cable from 2009 described [[police brutality]], including [[torture]], as common and pervasive, and the government's efforts to combat it as ineffective and lacking in political will.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/us-embassy-cables-documents/187359|title=US embassy cables: Police brutality in Egypt|work=The Guardian |location=UK|date 28 January 2011|accessdate=29 January 2011}}</ref> The [[Egyptian Organisation for Human Rights]] has documented 567 cases of torture, including 167 deaths, by police that occurred between 1993 and 2007.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/6943704.stm|title=Egyptian police sued for boy's death|publisher=BBC News|date=13 August 2007|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref> On 6 June 2010 [[Death of Khaled Mohamed Saeed|Khaled Mohamed Saeed died under disputed circumstances]] in the [[Sidi Gaber]] area of [[Alexandria]]. Multiple witnesses testified that Saeed was beaten to death by the police.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/anger-alexandria-we%E2%80%99re-afraid-our-own-government|title=Anger in Alexandria: 'We're afraid of our own government'|work=[[Almasry Alyoum]]|date=25 June 2010|accessdate=13 July 2010}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Two witnesses affirm Alexandria victim beaten by police|author=|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/two-witnesses-affirm-alex-victim-beaten-police|work=[[Almasry Alyoum]]|date=19 June 2010|accessdate=26 January 2011}}</ref> Activists rallying around a Facebook page called "We are all Khaled Said" succeeded in bringing nationwide attention to the case.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Levinson |first=Charles |url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748703445904576118502819408990.html |title=Wall Street Journal |work=The Wall Street Journal |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> [[Mohamed ElBaradei]], former head of the [[International Atomic Energy Agency]], led a rally in Alexandria against alleged abuses by the police and visited Saeed's family to offer condolences.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2010/06/201062642955204618.html|title=ElBaradei leads anti-torture rally|publisher=Al Jazeera English|date=26 June 2010|accessdate=13 July 2010}}</ref>
 
===Corruption===
===Corruption===
â
[[File:Police in civilian cloth beating a protester in Cairo 1.png|thumb|175px|Baltageya beating a protester in Cairo]]
 
{{main|Crime in Egypt}}
{{main|Crime in Egypt}}
â
[[Political corruption]] in the Mubarak administration's [[Ministry of Interior (Egypt)|Ministry of Interior]] has risen dramatically, due to the increased power over the institutional system necessary to prolong the presidency.<ref name="Egypt after Mubarak">{{Cite book|last=Rutherford|first=Bruce|title=Egypt after Mubarak: liberalism, Islam, and democracy in the Arab world|publisher=[[Princeton University Press]]|year=2008|month=November|isbn= 0-6911-3665-3}}</ref> In 2010, [[Transparency International]]'s [[Corruption Perceptions Index]] report assessed Egypt with a CPI score of 3.1, based on perceptions of the degree of corruption from business people and country analysts (with 10 being clean and 0 being totally corrupt).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.transparency.org/policy_research/surveys_indices/cpi/2010/results|title=CPI 2010 table|publisher=[[Transparency International]]|accessdate=26 October 2010}}</ref> The deployment of plainclothes forces paid by Mr. Mubarakâs ruling party, ''Baltageya'' ({{lang-ar|Ø¨ÙØ·Ø¬ÙØ©}}), has been a hallmark of the Mubarak government.<ref name="Gunfire Rings Out as Protesters Clash">{{Cite news|author=David KirkpAtrick|coauthors=Kareem Fahim|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/26/world/middleeast/26egypt.html|title=Gunfire Rings Out as Protesters Clash|work=The New York Times |date=03 February 2011| accessdate=03 February 2011}}</ref>
+
[[Political corruption]] in the Mubarak administration's [[Ministry of Interior (Egypt)|Ministry of Interior]] has risen dramatically, due to the increased power over the institutional system necessary to prolong the presidency.<ref name="Egypt after Mubarak">{{Cite book|last=Rutherford|first=Bruce|title=Egypt after Mubarak: liberalism, Islam, and democracy in the Arab world|publisher=[[Princeton University Press]]|year=2008|month=November|isbn= 0-6911-3665-3}}</ref> In 2010, [[Transparency International]]'s [[Corruption Perceptions Index]] report assessed Egypt with a CPI score of 3.1, based on perceptions of the degree of corruption from business people and country analysts (with 10 being clean and 0 being totally corrupt).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.transparency.org/policy_research/surveys_indices/cpi/2010/results|title=CPI 2010 table|publisher=[[Transparency International]]|accessdate=26 October 2010}}</ref>
